N95 mask packaging has a label or verbiage indicating protection down to 0.3microns. N95 mask are the gold standard of masks. COVID-19 viruses are 0.125 microns.
HOW MASKS WORK : A basic understanding of how masks work helps. Masks are filters. The material used in a standard surgical mask (by far the more common type of mask) reduces transmission of bacteria. Both bacteria and viruses are microscopic microbes, but they differ greatly. Bacteria are living cells, while a virus is a particle that requires a host cell to replicate. A coronavirus virion (particle) is spherical, averaging around 125 nanometers in diameter. Compare that to bacteria’s 1,000-nm size. It’s a grape compared to a grapefruit. A surgical mask whose purpose is to block bacteria will do little to prevent passage of the smaller coronavirus particle.
SHORTCOMINGS IN THE CURRENT DESIGNS Problematically, masks seem like they weren’t designed for people’s actual faces. What’s more, tying the straps around your head might cause the mask to pucker at the cheeks, creating gaps; and gaps above the cheekbones result in an upward flow of breath that fogs glasses. Even just talking can make the mask creep down from the nose. Yawning does the same but more quickly. Biomechanically, face movement and mask movement don’t align—the jaw’s pivot point is near the ear, while the mask flexes near the mouth.

How about copying the body's defenses? One way the body defends against viruses is via nose hairs coated in bacteria. Virus lands on the hair, bacteria eat the virus. Can we make an artificial version? Fibers coated in specially chosen, safe bacteria. Bacteria used to ferment food might work?

Or maybe leave the bacteria out of the product as it is sold to consumers. Sell masks with hygroscopic filter fibers coated in a super thin layer of some sort of nutrient gel-- as you breathe, your own bacteria colonize the gel.

Or lower tech-- use what we already have. Instead of filters of special manufactured fibers, how about having people pack their mask with their own hair clippings? We have to have some sort of microbiome of bacteria, etc. growing on our hair, right? That microbiome should be safe from the possibility of making us sick or triggering an allergic reaction.

What about a hydrophilic material for the borders/elastic/interior with a hydrophobic shell over the front?  The moisture in your breath is wicked away to the sides of your mask and evaporates, creating a dry environment the viruses would need to pass through in order to circumvent the hydrophobic shell which might not easily fit as snugly and could splash onto nearby exposed skin (which would still be preferable to you inhaling it).  Also probably easier to make flexible and tight fitting hydrophilic material as well as more rigid and sturdy hydrophobic material.

There is a way to "sterilize" N95 masks without damaging them: just WAIT the appropriate number of days for the virus to die on its own, and then re-use. I had a bunch of these masks when the corona thing blew up, because my work gets dusty and I like to stock up on things, and I just put thirteen masks into rotation: use one, then put it in a paper bag, write the day's date on the bag, and toss it in a drawer to be used again after nine days had passed. Then use a different one the next day, and so on. Some days I didn't go anywhere, so I didn't need a mask, and sometimes I needed two in the same day, but thirteen masks in rotation were plenty, and each mask could be reused many times. After a while I started logging the number of hours each mask was worn as well, so I'd have a better idea of when it would need to be retired and replaced.

This is a whole lot of reinventing the wheels.

We already have very good reusable respirators. They are your half face or full face respirators used in industries or things like asbestos removal. They are reusable, can be washed and disinfected. The filters cannot be washed, but the ones with hard casings can be wiped down with soap, bleach, and disinfectants. The particulate contaminants are trapped in the HEPA filter media.

Best part? Unlike these unproven masks with tiny filter media surface, which increases breathing resistance, the respirators use large filters and they are easier to breath through and usable for half a year or more. And guess what, unlike these experimental masks, the respirators are already on the market. There are dozens of models from tens of makers, and they are already certified. With the right filters, you also have chemical protection. I already own several. They work perfectly well.
